lines.content: This is a project template for a greenfield Java project. It's named after the Java mascot _Duke_. Given below are instructions on how to use it.
Prerequisites: JDK 11, update Intellij to the most recent version.
1. Open Intellij (if you are not in the welcome screen, click `File` > `Close Project` to close the existing project first)
1. Open the project into Intellij as follows:
1. Select the project directory, and click `OK`.
1. If there are any further prompts, accept the defaults.
1. Configure the project to use **JDK 11** (not other versions) as explained in [here](https://www.jetbrains.com/help/idea/sdk.html#set-up-jdk).
In the same dialog, set the **Project language level** field to the `SDK default` option.

3. After that, locate the `src/main/java/duke/Duke.java` file, right-click it, and choose `Run Duke.main()` (if the code editor is showing compile errors, try restarting the IDE). If the setup is correct, you should see something like the below as the output:

Duke.assertThis((descIdx + 9) < dueIdx, "Task description cannot be empty.");
Duke.assertThis((descIdx + 6) < fromIdx, "Task description cannot be empty.");
Duke.assertThis((fromIdx + 7) < toIdx, "Start date/time cannot be empty.");
Duke.assertThis(inputs.length > 1, "Please indicate which task(s) to apply to.");

* Represents a Parser to parse date and time.

* Expects input to be formatted as "YYYY-MM-DD" (fixed to "-" separator).
* @param dateStr String representation of a date.
* Parses a string representation of a date into LocalDate.
* Expects input to be formatted as "YYYY-MM-DD" but separator is arbitrary.
* Arbitrary separator needs to be specified.
* @param dateStr String representation of a date.
* @param separator Separator used to separate the day, month, year.

* @param separator Character separating the date and time.
* @return Date and time in a LocalDateTime instance.
public LocalDateTime parseDateTime(String str, char separator) {
